node.text:
⚫It was concentrated in what is today Greece and along the western coast of Turkey.
⚫However, ancient Greek colonists established cities all around the Mediterranean and along the coast of the Black Sea.
⚫Ancient Greek civilization flourished from the period following Mycenaean civilization, which ended about 1200 BCE, to the death of Alexander the Great, in 323 BCE.
⚫By that time, Greek cultural influence had spread around the Mediterranean and, through Alexander the Great’s campaign of conquest, as far afield as India.
⚫The civilization of ancient Greece has been immensely influential on language, politics, educational systems, philosophy, science, and the arts.
🏛️FOLLOW me @ancient.scientist to enjoy more and more posts about our world's marvelous History.❤

node.text:
⚫It is a historical and archaeological city in southern Jordan.
⚫By the 2nd century BC Petra was the capital city of Nabataeans kingdom.
⚫Petra is famous for its rock-cut architecture and water conduit system.
⚫The Treasury (Al Khazneh) is the most known building in the city.
⚫In 2007, Al-Khazneh was voted one of the New 7 Wonders of the World.
⚫Petra is also called the 'Rose City' because of the colour of the stone from which it is carved.
⚫It has been a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1985.
⚫UNESCO has described Petra as "one of the most precious cultural properties of man's cultural heritage".
⚫Visitor numbers reached 1.1 million in 2019.
Credit : @natgeo

node.text:
(Cattedrale di Santa Maria del Fiore )
⚫Located their in Florence, Italy.
⚫The basilica is one of Italy's largest churches, and its dome is the largest brick dome ever constructed.
⚫The construction begun in 1296 in the Gothic style to a design of Arnolfo di Cambio.
⚫But by the beginning of the 15th century, after a hundred years of construction, the structure was still missing its dome.
⚫In 1436, Filippo Brunelleschi completed the structure by building the dome.
.

node.text:
🔘The Royal Kurgan🔘
⚫It dates back to the 4th century BC, and located in eastern Crimea.
⚫The burial is located in the present-day Kerch, which developed out of the ancient Greek town Panticapaeum founded by Miletus.

⚫The mound is almost 20 metres high and its base perimeter is about 250 meters.
⚫The total height of the burial chamber is 8.84 meters.

⚫During the excavations in the years 1833 until 1837, the kurgan was opened.
⚫It contained only remnants of a wooden sarcophagus, so it was probably robbed long ago.
⚫Christian symbols carved on the walls suggest that the grave rooms served early Christians as a place of refuge and as a sanctuary.

node.text:
🔘The Hanging Pillar of Lepakshi Temple🔘
⚫It is located in the village of Lepakshi, District of Andhra Pradesh, India.

⚫It was built in the 16th century and is also known as Veerabhadra temple.
⚫Among the 70 stone pillars, there is one that hangs from the ceiling!

⚫The base of the pillar barely touches the ground and is possible to pass objects such as a thin sheet of paper or a piece of cloth from one side to the other.

⚫The temple features many sculptures of god, goddesses, dancers and musicians, and hundreds of paintings all over the walls, columns and ceiling.

⚫At the front of the temple is a large bull, the mount of Shiva, which is carved from a single block of stone, and could be one of the largest of its type in the world.(last pic)

node.text:
🔘The theatre of Hierapolis🔘
⚫Hierapolis ("Holy City") was an ancient Greek city located on hot springs in classical Phrygia, Turkey.

⚫The theatre at Hierapolis was built in the second century AD under the Roman Emperor Hadrian during a period of extensive rebuilding following a devastating earthquake in 60 AD.
⚫It was later renovated under Septimus Severus (193-211 AD).

⚫The facade is 300 feet (91 m) long, the full extent of which remains standing.
⚫In the cavea there are 45 rows of seats, recent reconstruction efforts have restored most of the cavea which could accommodate approximately 15,000 people.

⚫At this time, the scaenae frons was modified and decorated with elaborate limestone and marble carvings.
⚫Although the exterior is relatively unassuming as viewed from the front, the interior contains one of Anatolia's most complete and best-preserved collection of Greco-Roman theatre decorations.

⚫In 343 AD the scaenae was renovated and the orchestra was altered so that it could hold aquatic displays.
⚫In the later years of the Roman Empire the orchestra was converted into a cellar.

node.text:
🔘The Mask Temple🔘
⚫Located at the archaeological site of Lamanai, Belize.
⚫This Maya civilization structure is the smallest of three excavated pre-Columbian temples at Lamanai.
⚫The construction popably began at c. 200 BC, and the temple was modified until c. 1300 AD.
⚫On the right side of the temple there is a carved mask , another mask had been covered by a stone wall on the left side; it was uncovered in 2011.
⚫Like the rest of the temple, the masks are made from limestone.
⚫The masks are 4 meters (13 feet) tall and have Olmec facial features, particularly its upturned lip and broad nose.
⚫The masks were a much later addition, dating c. 400 AD, about 600 years after the temple's original construction.
🐊The masks are adorned with the headdress of a crocodile ( Lamanai means "Submerged Crocodile")
⚫Inside the Mask Temple is a tomb that holds the remains of a man with jade and shell jewelry.
⚫Nearby the temple is a second, smaller tomb holding the remains of a woman.
⚫Both tombs date from around the same time and likely hold two of Lamanai's former rulers.

🔘Mummies: Secrets of the pharaohs🔘
⚫It's a "Magellantv" documentary that takes us on a journey to the royal tombs of Egypt and explores the history of ancient Egyptian society as told through the mummies of the past.

⚫In this documentary explorers and scientists are piecing together new archaeological and genetic clues of Egyptian mummies and providing a window into the fascinating and mysterious world of the pharaohs.

⚫It discusses the mummification process, how was done and the ingredients they used?
⚫How did the Egyptians imagine the afterlife would be like?

⚫In the documentary you would see a modern experiment to mummify a body!
⚫How DNA extracted from ancient mummies could help us nowadays?

node.text:
🔘The Tropaeum Alpium🔘
 ⚫It's a Roman trophy located in La Turbie ,France .
 
 ⚫The Trophy was built in 6 BC in honor of Augustus to celebrate his definitive victory over the 45 tribes who populated the Alps.
 ⚫The monument as partially restored is 35 meters high.
 
 ⚫When built, according to the architect, the base measured 35 meters in length, the first platform 12 meters in height, and the rotunda of 24 columns with its statue of an enthroned Augustus is 49 metres high.
 
 ⚫One of the stones of the tower, which Pliny the Elder transcribed, contained the names of the tribes.
 
 ⚫In 1705, when war broke out between Savoy and France during the War of the Spanish Succession, Louis XIV ordered the destruction of all fortresses in the region, including this one.
 
 ⚫The monument was partially restored in 1929 with funds from American philanthropist Edward Tuck.
 
🏛️👉Follow me @ancient.scientist to enjoy more and more posts about our world's marvellous History.❤

🔘The Castle of Coca🔘
⚫It is a castle located in the Coca municipality, central Spain.

⚫The castle was constructed in the 15th century and has been considered to be one of the best examples of Spanish Mudejar brickwork which incorporates Moorish Muslim design and construction with Gothic architecture.

⚫The double walls are 2.5 m thick and it's circled by a deep dry moat.

⚫It's made up of two square baileys separated by a passageway.

⚫Both show polygonal towers at the corners.
Due to its great splendour, it was used more as a palace than as a fortress.

node.text:
🔘Lyuba: A Mummified Baby Mammoth🔘
⚫She is a female woolly mammoth who died about 42,000 years ago at the age of 30 to 35 days.
⚫She is one of the best preserved mammoth mummy in the world, and was discovered in the frozen tundra of Siberia.

⚫Lyuba's body suffered some damage in the process of her discovery, with dogs having chewed off her right ear and a part of her tail, but remained largely intact.
⚫She weighed 50 kg (110 lb), was 85 centimetres (33.5 in.) high and measured 130 centimetres (51 in.) from trunk to tail, roughly the same size as a large dog.

⚫Lyuba is believed to have suffocated by inhaling mud as she struggled while bogged down in deep mud in the bed of a river which her herd was crossing.
⚫Following death, her body may have been colonized by lactic acid-producing bacteria, which "pickled" her, preserving the mammoth in a nearly pristine state.

⚫At the time of discovery, the mammoth was remarkably well-preserved; her eyes and trunk were intact and some fur remained on her body.
⚫Lyuba's organs and skin are in perfect condition, and scientists were able to identify milk from her mother in her stomach.
⚫Now located in the Shemanovskiy Museum and Exhibition Center in Salekhard, Russia.

🐘👉Follow me @ancient.scientist to enjoy more and more posts about our world's marvellous History.

node.text:
🔘Lichtenstein Castle🔘
⚫It is a Gothic Revival castle located in southern Germany.

⚫It was designed by Carl Alexander Heideloff and its name means "shining stone" or "bright stone".

⚫The palace was built on the foundations of an old knight's castle and was completed in 1842.

⚫The castle was damaged during World War II, but efforts to restore it began in the immediate aftermath of the war.

⚫With great attention to detail, Lichtenstein lets the romanticism live on with its architectural style and furnishings.

👉Follow me @ancient.scientist to enjoy more and more posts about our world's marvellous History.

node.text:
🔘The hermitage of San Michele Arcangelo🔘
⚫It is a small church located on the slopes of Mount Altino , Formia , Italy.
⚫The rock sanctuary, dedicated to St. Michael the Archangel , dates back to 830.
⚫However, the facade of stone, which closes a natural cavity, was rebuilt in the style Gothic Revival in the late 19th century .
⚫The façade faces the west is crowned by a rose window, which provides light for the dark interior.
⚫At the end of the cave, a small niche in the rocks holds the statue of Saint Michael the Archangel.
⚫According to local tale, the statue of the saint, initially worshiped elsewhere, decided to move to the cave on the Aurunci Mountains.
⚫Every time the statue would be returned to its original location, it would then end up returning to the present site!

👉Follow me @ancient.scientist to enjoy more and more posts about our world's marvellous History.

📸Photo by @claudia_depaolis_photography

node.text:
🔘The Gymnasium of Salamis🔘
⚫Located in Salamis , Cyprus( the legendary birthplace of Aphrodite).
⚫The current Gymnasium with its columned palaestra were built over the ruins of an ealier Hellenistic gymnasium in the 2nd century AD during Trajan and Hadrian’s reign after Salamis had been greatly damaged in 116 AD during Jewish revolt.

⚫The gymnasium was used by citizens to exercise their bodies and minds.
⚫It has a vast exercise ground with marble columns, swimming pools ,bathing facilities, and large palaestra, which was used for wrestling and general training.

⚫In the south west corner there are latrines set(rest room) with a capacity of 44, and the water pipe and water tank are still visible.
⚫In the baths are remnants of frescoes and mosaic decorations.

⚫It was largely destroyed in the earthquakes of 332 and 342AD, then it was rebuilt by the Emperor Constantius, and a section to the east added.

⚫The statues had there heads or faces removed, as well as their hands it is thought to be done by early Christians.
